user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtBinFile2Mem:
```c
bool UtBinFile2Mem(void *Memory, const char *Filename, uint32 Length)
{
    FILE *fp;
    bool  Success;

    Success = false;
    if ((fp = fopen(Filename, "r")))
    {
        if (fread(Memory, Length, 1, fp) == 1)
        {
            Success = true;
        }
        fclose(fp);
    }
    else
    {
        UtAssert_Failed("UtBinFile2Mem: Error Opening %s: %s", Filename, strerror(errno));
    }

    return Success;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function UtBinFile2Mem:
#define UtAssert_Failed(__VA_ARGS__) UtAssertEx(false,UtAssert_GetContext(),__FILE__,__LINE__,__VA_ARGS__)
...
UtAssert_CaseType_t UtAssert_GetContext(void)
{
    return DefaultContext;
}
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
#define UtAssert_Failed(__VA_ARGS__) UtAssertEx(false,UtAssert_GetContext(),__FILE__,__LINE__,__VA_ARGS__)
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The macro definition itself does not contain unreachable code. UtAssert_Failed expands to a call expression UtAssertEx(false, UtAssert_GetContext(), __FILE__, __LINE__, __VA_ARGS__) — there is no construct that is provably never reached in this fragment. Therefore the fragment does not by itself violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1. Note the possible project-level concern: if UtAssertEx is implemented as a non‑returning function (e.g. it always aborts or enters an infinite loop), then any code immediately following a call to UtAssert_Failed would be unreachable, which would be a Rule 2.1 violation in those call sites. That violation would stem from the implementation/usage of UtAssertEx (and the places where UtAssert_Failed is invoked), not from the macro definition shown here.
